text: Draft. Clear golden yellow color white head. Aroma of white pepper and hay. Taste is clean and crisp peppery straw. Decent.
Light grain and some butter like an aunt trying to break your diet. Pours golden with ok head. Smooth easy finish. Bottle.
12oz can straw colored pour bubbly white cap aroma is cereal and grass taste is the same slight lingering bitterness

On tap at Sir Ben's. Scent is grassy, hay, and some light fruitiness. Maybe pear. Taste follows the nose. Some doughy character. A decent pilsner. Somewhat surprised by the rating. Definitely wouldn't be hard to knock back 6 to 16 though.

Keg @ Summit. Invitingly pale straw-colored pour with a small head. Lightly hazy. Nose is wonderfully inviting - waxy hay, fresh cut meadow. Lightly doughy yeast. Crisp and refreshing with a delicate earthy black pepper hop kiss on the finish. Mild fruitiness. Just a small bit of stewed corn character detracts from the experience a bit. Light body, soft and chalky. Surprisingly strong carb.

Pours a hazy straw color with big white pillowy head and nice sheets of lacing as the beer is consumed. Light grassy and floral hop notes which biscuity grain notes. Taste is light biscuit malt, grass and floral hops. Highly carbonated and easily drinkable.

Can, bbotmc. Hazy blond with a white head. Malty biscuit, a little grass, then some peach in the nose. Delicate bitterness, a little salty, and very refreshing. light body, slick feel, lively carbonation and a delicate bitter finish. Nice and quaffable.
Slightly hazy gold with white head. Aroma grainy, flowery, and earthy, with some bread notes. Taste earthy, vegetative, with a metallic finish.

12 ounce can from our friends at TIMERS LIQUOR in Racine, WI. This very smooth, cloudy amber, pils is so gentle on the palate, one cannot resist the "want another? temptation! After a couple of more, you realize the folks at SUMMIT BREWING in Saint Paul, MN, know their trade so well! A fine balance of malts, hops, yeast greets your taste buds. Nice lacing on the glass, with a beautiful blond head upon pouring. Simply excellent beer. Prosit!

Can sample at a tasting at Liors place. Thanks DSG. Slightly hazy yellow with white head. The aroma has notes of citrus, flowers and herbs. Sweetish and bitterish flavor with notes of herbs and citrus, crispy. Light to medium-bodied.

Bottle shared at a tasting at Lior Ds place. Better Beer Of The Month Club. Nice hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma of grains, lager yeast, slightly vegetal, and a bit of grassy hops. Flavor is quite dry, slightly sweetish, grainy, with lager yeast, and crisp bitterish grassy hops. Light to medium-bodied. Nice and refreshing.

On tap. A straw color with a large head and some lacing. Aroma of grain, some yeast and hint of malt sweetness. Taste of malt sweetness, bit of yeast and grain. Nice bitterness and a clean finish. Medium body, crisp and clean. Nicely crafted. very enjoyable.
Pours a clear, light gold with good-sized head. Aroma is very grassy. Flavor also grassy, with some malt and breadiness.
Can. Light sour milk, lemon, biscuit malt, and straw aroma. Hazy yellow with giant white head. Lightly sweet milky lemon, biscuit malt, and moderately bitter grass flavor. Good body. Very nice.

Draught pint at Greenfire in Rockford, IL, August 24th. Very, very pale gold with typical small bubbling continuing in the faintly hazy body; little head, a tiny hint of lacing...nose at first grassy and a little harsh, malty-honey sweetness comes in soon; quite fresh...though there are hints of that honey-malt sugar in the body, this is predominantly a very bitter and hoppy example, probably the most bitter (though not necessarily driest) example of the style Ive had in this Summer of Zwickels...theres also a faint cidery tartness that makes itself felt about halfway through the glass...overall an excellent rendition; I personally would like just a bit more bready malt presence, and a stronger more forward nose, and this is probably why Id pick New Glarus over this one, but Ill be picking up a 6-pack of this soon for more enjoyable comparisons.

355ml can. Wait a second this is my favorite style and a fresh top 50 rendition of it? Im intrigued... It pops open very sulphury, but it dissipates. The aroma is on point, fresh cut herbs, fresh bread. Flavor is crisp and bready, herbal, like many ive had overseas, i was skeptical by the first aroma blasting out of the can but this is a delight.
Pour from several cans over several days. Clear, light yellow with a nice white head. Crisp saaz nose and taste. Super clean beer. Totally crushable and delicious.
Can at a pool this summer. Crisp and true to style, but I dont think I liked this one as much as others have.

12 oz can shared by my brother in law. The pour is clear golden with a ½ inch white head. The aroma is hay, herbal and fresh cracker malt. The taste is great balance between the herbal grassy hay notes and the super clean and fresh cracker malt. The palate is light to bodied, great unfiltered mouth feel and a clean dry mineral herbal finish. Nicely executed beer in one of my favorite styles.

Very nice. Huge white frothy, long lasting head with lots of lace and a lovely yellow. Aroma is mown grass, spice, wet grain, hops. Flavors a bit like nose, bittersweet. Great carbonation. Very clean and refreshing. Hope they bring this back!

Tap - fair size foamy head, medium straw color, pretty balanced aroma and flavor - bready malt and earthy hops, full bodied finish, good overall 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12 ounce can. Pours a somewhat hazy pale gold with a nice white head. Aroma of malt, yeast, and floral. Taste is malt, yeast, floral, grain, and grass. Well made and very refreshing.
Tap at JL Beers Bismarck Im sticking light for now. Golden pour frothy white head. Nose is grainy and bread. Tastes of grains, grass, crackers, light lemon. Crisp. Pretty nice.

Can from TODD! Thanks!

A: Brilliant gold in color with a huge foamy white head. Theres a touch of bubbles in here, but no lacing.

N: Corn, sulfur, minerality, spent grain, light pine and earth, touch of green grape, and an underpinning of toast.

T: Decently bitter, nicely sweet.

M: Light body, crisp carbonation, no alcohol.

O: This is an excellent keller. Its well balanced and theres lots of flavor.

Can:
Hazed, pale yellow with a frothy white head.
Grain malt, yeast, honey aroma.
Taste is heavily malty, grains, lagery....
Nice full body and richness.
Mild grassy, straw bitter.
Excellent.

Pour is a hazy straw with a large white head. Aroma is a nice fresh baked biscuit with a a herbal European hop. Flavor is again a nice bready and chewy malt with a touch of honey sweetness. A decent hop follows the swallow. This is a pretty malt heavy pils but it is still full of flavor and refreshing at the same time.

Can - Clear straw yellow pour with a foamy white head. Nose is flowery, lightly herbal hops with a doughy, crackery dry malt. Taste is the same, with a light, sweet flowery hoppiness and a dry doughy breadiness. Light and highly carbonated body. Really good stuff.
Aroma is herbal/spicy hops and German yeast/malts. The flavor is German yeast, fruit and a long and complex mix of bitter, beery and herbal/spicy hops in the finish.

Pours light dull yellow with a bit of haze and a large white head. The aroma has clean pale pils malt, extra yeast, fresh dough and a rounded freshness. It has a medium body with soft carbonation. The taste has malt thats doughy but dry, rich without being sweet, light spice and grassy hops and a delicate balance to everything. Very pleasant.
Hazy pale straw pour, large fluffy head. Grains, lemon, grassy aroma. Grainy, fresh cut grass, light corn, light citrus, cracker malt. Lighter body, clean finish.
Excellent summer beer. Light and easy, some light lemon sweetness. Another winner from Summit.
Tap at Busters. Bright clear golden pour with a white head. Sweet grains, slick texture, very very well made.

Clear to hazy golden body with a quickly dissipating white head. Aromas of fresh cut grass, corn, some light hops, and crackers. Flavor mimics the aroma. This beer is on point, and true to style. Very solid.

12 oz. can from 12 pack. Pours clear gold straw color with a white head that dissipates to a slight film and decent lacing. Aroma is grassy straw light corn and hops showing up. Taste is a little bitter hop bite with grassy corn malt. Palate thin crisp and refreshing. I dig it!

7 oz. pour, on tap at Summit Beer Hall in St. Paul, Minnesota. Consumed on 6-17-16. Clear gold. Small amount of nearly white head. Good lacing. Light effervescence. I was expecting haziness given the style. Light, dry yet floral aroma. Pleasant smell. Grassy. A touch of urine in the smell. Dry, hay flavor. Watermelon. Pleasant. Light to medium body. Soft in the palate. Refreshing and drinkable. Fresh taste. Lively and fairly crisp but could stand to be crisper. Overall, a good and likable refresher but not nearly as outstanding as my fellow raters so far have made it out to be. I definitely wish it were far yeastier.

12oz can pours a pale clear yellow/straw with a large white head. Aroma of grassy hops, dry yeast, and honey biscuit malt. Crisp, smooth, sweet and dry, grainy malt hits yeast and dry grassy bitter hops. Simple, drinkable, and delicious. In my mind the ideal all around beer. I hope they continue brewing this past their 30 anniversary, Ill be buying it!

Can. Pours a near clear pale yellow with a white head that lasts throughout the beer. Aroma has lots of grain and hay with a great crisp grass note supporting. Flavor has same great crispness with light grain, hay and straw underlying.
Straw yellow colr with a medium head. Floral hop aroma. Big grainy malt flavor. Light earth hop character. Medium bitterness. Dry. Simple, but crazy drinkable.

I purchased a six pack of this. Where they went with 16 oz cans for the double IPA, they are selling this in 12 oz, and that seems backwards. In Franconia you are going to have this by the liter/half liter. I poured almost two cans into a Weihenstephaner dimpled mug. Initially a tall white head that fades quickly, but leaves thick lace on the glass and on top of the beer. Immediately recognizable as a keller bier from the first sip. There is lots of yeast, and crisp, dry malt. Some bread dough. Very dry. Aftertaste of light malt. Hops add a bitter flavor that works well with the malt flavor. They nailed the style. This is one of the best beers Summit has ever produced.

Pale yellow-golden color, with a slight haze, 1 inch white, thick head. Lots of visible carbonation. Sweet, bready, floral aroma. Good body and mouth feel. Sweet and mild initial taste with fruits and spices. The sweet malts are nicely balanced with hops, but this is not a bitter beer, it is malt and yeast forward, with a hint of banana & cloves from the yeasts. Very enjoyable, one of the better summer beers Ive had in awhile.
